The place was pretty much empty when we came in for dinner. I didn't feel like eating sushi so I had the chicken donburi. Big mistake! Why didn't I just order chicken teriyaki instead? Hello it's a teriyaki house after all. The chicken in the donburi seemed like it was just boiled in hot water. No taste, blah just BLAND! I basically paid $7 bucks to have 3 bites of it. I didn't even want to bring the rest home but as always I think to myself there's people out there that are less fortunate than me. 

If I ever come back I'm going with either sushi rolls or anything with the word teriyaki in it.
author: Tracy A.

description: I'm giving this place 1 star because even though the food is ok, the service is BEYOND terrible. I'm allergic to shellfish but I enjoy the beef teriyaki and tempura combo dinner (sans prawns of course). The harumaki (the imperial rolls) that come with dinner also have shrimp in them, and I cannot eat them. I called for take-out, made my usual order, but this time I asked if I could replace my harumkai for something without shrimp in it. The woman I spoke to told me no, even though the gyoza is the EXACT same price as the rolls for the exact same amount (according to their online menu). I said that was ok, but if should replace the rolls with something else that would be great! Her suggestion? Would you like more salad? Seriously? SALAD? Was she going to include a leaf or two more? Or maybe actually provide a decent amount of greens to dressing? Who knows. I said that wasn't really a comparable and if she could maybe include another ice cream or perhaps some extra tempura veggie pieces... She then tried to tell me to "order something else." Really?!  What else was I going to order?! I don't understand why this place, and this woman on the phone, are so unaccommodating. So even though the food is actually pretty alright, I don't think I'll be going back anytime soon. Terrible service!
author: Hannah P.

description:
No offense but I don't like to go to a Non-Japanese-Japanese restaurant.
But this place is all right. 
Most of menu are very large portion.
Big!
For exanple, Chicken Katsu and Ton-Katsu are good for 2.
I am not kidding. 
It is good for a reasonable family dinner.
author: Nobu K.

description: Love the fire and ice roll and the sea food salad is dee-lish!! Also, the seafood salad and crispy chicken salads are TO DIE FOR!! YUM YUM YUM! Noriega Terriaki Hoise never disappoints.
author: April V.

description:
Noriega T was good when it first opened but has since gone downhill.
my tempura was very oily and the sushi was just 'ok'.  probably would not eat here again.
author: n y.

description: My son took me to eat here because a couple of my co-workers said it was good. We had the $43.00 tray because it had a combination of rolls and sashimi. Our wait person was good but the food is not up to the standards of what we're used to. The sashimi is low grade,the slices were the biggest we've ever seen but it does not make up for the quality. The rolls were better than the sashimi but not by much. I'm glad I tried it but we will definitely not be back. The surprising thing was the place was packed for a Wed night so maybe we expect too much.
author: Theresa W.

description: Love the pink salmon roll! The interior is pretty nice. The food taste alright, but the pink salmon roll is awesome! The prices are alright. Pretty good customer services!
author: Jane Z.

description: The best part about this restaurant is that it delivers!  Imagine that...craving sushi, have kids at home and don't want to go out...no problem.  We have eaten at the restaurant as well and the sushi quality is always good and dependable.  Great place for families as they recently added a children's menu.  Love it.
author: lucy w.

description:
I visit this resturant at least twice a month.  There is a reason for that.  It's good! When I'm not dropping into the actually resturant, I'm ordering delivery service.  

The food is really good.  Sushi rolls, sashmi, entree dishes, etc.  Anything on the menu is top notch.  The prices are par with other good sushi joints.  You can get tons of food for $20ish that will probably fill you tummy.  

Service is execellent!  The worker there are friendly and nice.  

This place can get pretty packed during dinner hours, as do most good resturant.  Parking can be a pain sometimes.  

Overall,  GREAT place!
author: eric l.

description:
Every bleeping time I order from this place, I get close to botchulism.  Like a schmuck, my husband and I decided to give them another chance the other night.  We ordered hamachi sashimi, 6 pcs oysters on the half shell, chasu ramen, and a tempura/salmon teriyaki dinner, 1 side order rice and 1 green tea ice cream.

Wouldn't you know the exact same thing again?  gosh, I never learn!  Even the soup made me sick.  Soup, cooked no less!  They must have some serious bacteria culture thing going on there!!!
author: Rhodora M.

description: I can tolerate an occasional bad order but it's now one too many.  I have had stale sashimi, bad oysters, overcooked dried out chicken here.   Used to be better for food and service, but it has been declining.
author: Robert C.

description: Neightborhood sushi eatery.  Food is pretty good, although I can't say is the best I've ever eaten.  My favorite on the menu is the sea bass and teriyaki combo - delicious and inexpensive! Pitfall: service can be slow.  Sometimes you and the other 3 tables of patrons will wonder where all the wait staff went.  Staff meeting perhaps? Important game on TV in the back? Who knows... Overall, if you're in the mood for sushi, in the vicinity, and don't wanna drive any further, Noriega Teriyaki House will satisfy.
author: S. D.

description: Sushi is at best average. Service is horrible. They gave me the wrong bill but I decided to be nice and notify them otherwise it would have been 30 bucks for a 90 dollar meal and 2 yelp stars instead of 1 for great value!
author: Eric L.

description: Get the tempura and sashimi, you won't be disappointed! The lunch specials come with cucumber appetizer, miso soup, rice and REAL GREEN TEA. Seriously they do a great tea with real leaves and rice! The ambience is great and they're open all day.
author: Andrew C.

description: Fish not fresh? Improper preparation of the food? Just unsanitary kitchen/employees? Whatever it is, be careful as i came in wanting some sushi but left with a stomach virus. Had the sashimi combo deluxe? Which is 3 hamachi, 3 salmon, 3 tuna, and 3 oysters. LUCKILY, they were out of oysters and we had a substitution or else who knows what else might've happened to me. As with any sushi place, be careful.
author: J K.

description:
So Kevo and I visit Noriega Teriyaki...this is my first time. 

Okay, the food is very mediocre but big in portions, but the waitress was an aloof little girl who thought she was my bigger sister.  She was big little girl, if you know what I mean.  Think, overgrown midget that's kinda cute and you kinda just wanna do it, if you know what I mean.  Yeah.  And she called ME fat because I ordered ramen AND chicken teriyaki.  The nerve.  I love this girl.  She then suggested I ate sherbert as part of my desert that comes with my teriyaki chicken as opposed to green tea or coffee.  FINE!  I'll eat your sherbert.  It came, and it was pink.  Some white and some orange.  GREAT!  It left a sour after taste.  I looked over to my right and there was an old couple: and old white dude that was barely awake and an old asian dudette who helped him up as they left.  How rofrigginmantic.  I want to grow old and eat at Noriega Teriyaki House just like them!
author: Hodie K.

description:
Two stars only because they have gigantic portions.  But honestly, I'd rather have tiny portions of DELICIOUS food than huge portions of the saltiest food I've ever had at a Japanese restaurant. 

I ordered Salmon wrapped in seaweed and deep fried, which in theory should be pretty decent, but they poured this thick ass cornstarch sauce all over it and made it soggy and too salty.  Their Salmon was very fishy, too, meaning it was not fresh at all.  I hate that more than anything.  When Salmon has that fishy taste, it really means you should THROW THAT STUFF OUT!  I only ate one piece of my order.  Their fried potato was good though.... Relative to everything else.

I also tried some grilled Salmon which was also too salty, but I just wiped off all the sauce on the plate so it was bearable.  Then I tried the Chicken Karaage, which was pretty decent.  Although it tasted just like panko breaded chicken, so it was like chicken katsu to me.  Also had their spider roll, which was decent, but nothing exceptional.  

Sure, they give you miso, and salad, and ice cream, but the green tea ice cream was too creamy and did not taste enough like tea.  I think my favorite part about this meal was their ice water flavored with lemon.  But I don't go to restaurants for that... so I'm never going here again.
author: Anna T.

description:
Normally, when I came here, I order their sashimi combo. The temptation here is that included in the combo are three pieces of raw oyster with sauce. For the price, they're more than satisfactory.

Years ago, they had a waitress that seemed to never smile and had an unfriendly look. At least now she does not appear to be there anymore, so that's a plus.
author: H K.

description: I had a meal there with my nephew in the middle of December last year (2010).  My nephew was house shopping and we happened upon this place that was right around the corner.  We sat at the bar and enjoyed the food.  We had a ton of food.  Well, maybe not quite that much but everything was delicious and I was a little stuffed by the time we finished.    Also, everyone working there was very friendly just as most people have mentioned in the other reviews.
author: michael m.

description:
I don't usually eat oyaku don at restaurants. 

It truly is comfort food for me. 
But I'm tiring 
of the usual 
chicken teriyaki, karaage, or katsu. 

Yesterday, I also decided to change up my choice of lunch establishments. 

I decided on Noriega Teriyaki House and oyaku don. 

The oyaku don was decent and quickly made.  

The price was reasonable 
and the service, 
friendly. I found a parking stall right out front.

It is very decent and reasonable. 

Like Nobu, 
I don't care too much for FXXX imitations. 
But they do a good job.

edit: very good service for take out & phone orders. They also delivered to the outer richmond. Added a star.

edit: Nobu corrected me. It is Oyako-Don. 
Too bad I don't do a good job
of imitating Nobu. Or
I would have more people

who thought I was funny.
author: Kevo M.

description:
Great Japanese restaurant!  This place isn't far from where I live, and whenever my parents and I have time to meet up (amidst the craziness of dental school), we ALWAYS go here!

Street parking can be difficult to find, but it's best to go here early (i.e. before 6pm) to avoid the crowd.  The food, tea, atmosphere, service is excellent, and all placed at a reasonable price.  I usually get the tempura and chicken or beef teriyaki... and my parents get sashimi or chirashi (full of raw fish).  They love this restaurant too!

I've never had their takeout... but I plan on having it one of these days.  =P
author: Nancy H.

description:
We went there last night. Nothing special at all. My wife and I have ordered their delivery food before and have always liked it. We decided to try the place out in person and we were somewhat disappointed. We both had the Sashimi boat. I do not believe the fish was as fresh as it could of been. I actually believe they did not purchase Sashimi grade fish for their Sushi or Sashimi. What they served was not the best graded fish to begin with and then the thought of serving it as Sashimi, well that just doesn't work. 

We also had the deep fried California Roll. That was the only saving grace of the whole experience.

We each had their overpriced beer.

Bottom line is we aren't going back. It was overpriced for what you receive. 

We will continue to use their delivery service but definately aren't going back to dine in.

Wayne
author: Wayne B.

description: We've been going to Noriega Teriyaki for years... since back in the day when they were at their smaller location with a smaller menu.... they keep evolving their menu, adding a nice variety of options... we stopped in for a bite to eat last Friday night, and as always, the food was great! One thing we can always count on, is no matter when we decided to stop in, or when we call to take out, we know that to food is going to be good. There have been a couple of times when we've stopped in, and the teriyaki seems a bit saltier than usual, but we suspected there might have been a substitute chef on that day. If you're looking for some good japanese food or sushi, I'd recommend stopping in. The portions are fairly large, and the line out the door is a sign of something too. They are always sure not to have you wait too long, when necessary, they open up the back dining area for the additional seating....
author: Cster x.

description:
I can't say that I've ever ordered anything but sushi from Noriega.  You can find me on any given night, sitting at the sushi bar - seat #8 - that's my seat!

I'm no sushi expert, but I really like this place for their innovative rolls.  Being the creature of habit that I am, I usually order the tuna tartar or the tuna poke, followed by the oysters.  Then I go with a nice hamachi nigiri and sake nigiri - which always tastes fresh.

Then comes the fun - woooo, it's ROLL time! Feeling adventurous one night, we ordered the "No Name Roll."  I would like to rename this roll the, "Holy Sushi This Kicks Ass" roll.  I have no friggin clue what the hell they put in there, but damn it's good!  There's some sorta tropical roll that has thinly sliced ripe mango on top...oh mama!

The service is sorely lacking.  I think that's why we sit at the sushi bar, so we can cut out the slacker wait-peeps.  If you ever go and sit at a table and wonder why the service is so slow, it's because they're all up at the front register goofing around (I should know because the sushi bar is right there and I usually sit there while eating my tuna tartar wondering why these peeps aren't refilling my empty tea cup or taking away the masses of dirty sushi plates that are piling up because I'm eating way too much damn sushi!).

Good times.
author: Christy L.

description: The food is all right.  It's the service that needs improving at lunch time.  Regular servers, who are accustomed to us, will ignore us upon entering the restaurant.  It seems to be an option for them whether or not they wish to seat you when you enter.  And there are empty tables available.  A few servers are not good in articulating and will get flustered, or worse, defensive if asked anything even about bringing the wrong order.  To pay the bill one has to flag down any server as they congregate in the main dining room which is near the cash register.
author: Luisa T.

description:
not impressed with this place.  the sushi was fishy/smelly/chewy...kind of gross. the teriyaki chicken was good though...We came with 4 people, 3 of us got our dinner and finished it....the last dinner never came...even though we asked the waitress several times...our friend never got his food and left hungry...we were too much in a hurry to wait...totally sucks

they offered us ice cream even though the teriyaki dinners came with ice cream...lame!
author: sonya h.

description: The staff is friendly. The kara-age chicken, which was recommended to me, was pretty good though the sauce was a bit too sweet for my taste.
author: Edward T.

description:
I've been going to Noriega Teriyaki House for a few years and it has never failed me yet.

Parking: Difficult if you go from 7pm-8pm. I usually go there either before or after that time period.

Decor: Nice, simple and clean.

Appetizers : Soup and salad are your standard affair that come with your meal. I do like the cucumbers that accompany your meal as they are quite tasty.

Sushi: It's good but not the "best" I've ever had. The spider rolls and caterpillar rolls are some of my favorites there.

Entree: I stick with the bento box combination beef  teriyaki & tempura or I'll switch up and get the salmon teriyaki or katsu.

Dessert: The coffee ice cream is a nice treat at the end of the meal. I really never cared for green tea ice cream.

Service: I'm never left wanting and wishing my server would come by and see if there was anything else I needed. They are very attentive to their customers and food is brought out nice and hot and when you're done the dishes are removed equally as fast.

Overall: I will continue to come to this restaurant because of the food,service and price are all good in my book.
author: Mario O.

description:
Been here a couple times and the fish has been fresh each time i've gone. Portions are large, but I don't feel that they have sacrificed any quality for quantity. 10-15 bucks will probably get you a pretty good meal (unless you're like me and you order a dinner/lunch combo AND a roll, then aim for $20).

I didn't like the raw oysters. tasted kinda funky. and sandy.
author: Will T.

description: The 3.5 Star review sums it up well! It's not great, but ok. Service is really nice and food is good, but can be better. Stop by if your in the area and are really hungry, but don't expect to be wowed.
author: TheOneAndOnly T.

description:
I live down the street from this place.  

I've eaten here several times.  I usually will get the chicken or beef Teriyaki or tempura.  They're okay, but not the best.  I got another plate and I can't recall what it was, but it was salty and I think they let the batter sit before they cooked it so it came out soggy.  Oh well.  Can't win, can you??

It's a good spot if you want sushi or something quick.  The thing that sucks though is to use your credit/debit card, there's a minimum of $15 which sucks ass.  They got pissed at me once, but went ahead and let me charge my order even though it was just under $15.  It's lame.

My roommate's had the sushi and it's ok.  Though again, she's straight from Japan so I think a lot of sushi here in the States isn't quite up to her standards.  But she'll eat it.

I only go here because it's close.  I don't think I'd go out of my way to come here if I didn't live down the street from it.
author: imelda j.

description:
My fiance and I used to go to to "Noriyaki" pretty much every day. The lovely woman who waited on us knew our order by heart. Needless to say, we like it. A lot.
Their wakame (seaweed salad) is my favorite of all I've tried so far. 
Big plus for the friendly service. Their decor could use a little spice, but the fake singing bird hanging on the trees in the center of the restaurant is classic.
author: Sarah C.

description: Since i live by beach this is actually very good sushi, i order to go once a week, fish is fresh
author: Christine L.

description: We've only ordered over the phone, so considering it's delivery, it's easy sushi or teriyaki. The sashimi "appetizer" is actually really big. Only problem is that if you order both sushi and teriyaki, the teriyaki will be lukewarm, so it's probably best to order only teriyaki or only sushi if it's for delivery.
author: Bunny C.

description:
That's more like 2.5 stars than 3. Tonight we ate at the NTH after having not been here for awhile. I wanted to go to Sushi Zen or Fujiyama-ya. But, the BF wanted to go to this place. 

We shared tuna poki (Sushi Zen's is better), gyoza (decent), seaweed salad (good), baked mussels (yum) and a dinner special. The dinner special was California roll, tempura and chicken teriyaki. The dinner special comes with miso soup (tasty), rice, salad (good dressing), an orange rind and ice cream for dessert. The teriyaki was very good as was the tempura. I wasn't impressed with the California roll at all. : ( 

The food was decent enough. The thing that I hated about tonight was our server seemed SO BOTHERED that we dared to ask him for anything: a fork and water refills. I only tipped 12% when I usually tip 20% or higher when service is excellent. I am sure the restaurant is family-owned and run. Look, kid...it's not my fault your parent's/extended family own this joint. You are here to serve me. I already had a long day at work, so suck it up. I always provide service with a smile. You really need to *learn* to do the same.
author: Gigi F.

description:
Exclnt service here! 
Good fresh fish. The fire and ice roll is a bit odd. It's a fried calamari roll with chili sauce and mayo. Strange indeed. We were told to try the beef teriyaki and it didn't disappoint. Salad and dressing were awesome. Gyoza were a little big, which made them seem less japanese and less crunchy good. More like standard potstickers. It's true the green tea ice cream was tasty, and indeed small. But the kona coffee ice cream was even better. Overall pretty darn good.
author: Sean S.

description:
Go here if you don't want authentic japanese food.

Go here if you don't want to wait for a table.

Go here for the mostly ample parking.

Go here because it is the only non-chinese place in the neighborhood.

Go here because even though it is the only non-chinese restaurant, it is still run by chinese.

Go here if you're not planning on eating large portions of food.




I am japanese.  I am a bad cook.  I can cook japanese food better than this place.  Why don't you pay me to cook for you?
author: Kimiko Q.

description:
This is a great neighborhood Japanese restaurant. It's cozy and the service staff is a swift and friendly. I usually order the Teriyaki dinner special at $13.95 per person if I'm really hungry. This meal includes: tempura, beef teriyaki, salmon Isobe-age, and chicken karage. In addition you get the basic soup, sunomono, appetizer (harumaki), steamed rice, and ice cream. Most of the time I can't finish the meal, it's so much food. The sushi rolls are good too! 

Usually this place gets packed during dinner time on weekends so show up early (before 6PM). There's a back room if you want to have a private party. Thumbs up for the convenient location and portion size.
author: Candace F.

description:
I've been here several times in the past and my experience has been "okay".  The sushi is so-so, the sashimi could have been more fresh and their chicken katsu looked like chicken cutlet instead.  

I don't mind eating here, but it would not be my first choice if I were strolling down Noriega street, starving.

Two stars for the food and 1 extra for the friendly service.

Edit: My friend and I ended up having food poisoning from this place. We spent a day throwing up and fighting off a fever. Thank goodness it lasted only 1 day.  I wish I could've kept the 3 stars for this restaurant, but 3 hours at the hospital and having my man clean up vomit in front of my house did NOT make his day.
author: A L.

description:
sometimes the sashimi here are fresh, but most of the time its not. The food here is decent. Not bad not that great either. But coming here for parties can be a blast. Although its a typical japanese restaurant, you know how it is. its pretty expensive. And they don't really give you much. sometimes they even mess up my order. But i guess thats okay for me ... but for some people its not.

i do enjoy the Pink salmon rolllll ! Its awesome. one of my favorites
author: Andrew H.

description: This is my go to place because I live down the street. It's consistently delicious and the staff is fast and cordial.
author: Jessica J.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend on a Sunday night and they sat us down right away. They said they were going to close at 9:30 and we were one of the last people in the restaurant, so I was a little nervous that they were going to rush us, but they didn't rush us at all!  They took our order as soon as we were ready and were very patient.  
The Sushi rolls were great and the price of the food is reasonable for what you are getting.  The green tea ice cream was delicious, and when we were finished, the nice staff smiled and said goodbye as we left. Good food and customer service. Just for that I give them 5 stars...
author: H. A.

description:
The atmosphere here is very cool and the food is quite good.
I highly recommend the Steak Teriyaki, it is the best ever!
The prices are incredible- a full dinner for around $15.00.
author: Michael M.

description: I would usually give this place a 4/5 star but I'm going to give it a 3 instead. I used to love coming here when I went to go do laundry or when I was craving for some Japanese food. I had some ups and downs with this place and sadly the food quality is not how it used to be. The tuna poki was a tad on the frozen side. The tempura that I had order with my udon tasted like it was cooked in old oil that's been sitting there for to long. The tomago was on the frozen side and it was no longer fresh.The staff there is nice and friendly when it comes to their services.
author: Maile W.

description: The place had a few people on a weekend lunch. I just order chicken teriyaki Tasted like they cooked the chicken in ginger with garlic and poured some terriyaki sauce on top after they were done. If you go to a Japanese restaurant with a bunch of Chinese people there, it's going to taste more like Chinese food. Stick with Japanese food in a Japanese restaurant.
author: M C.

description:
I joined a few friends from out of town here last night for a dinner...  There were six of us total and we each shared four of the teriyaki combos.  The amount of food that we received was absurd!  I ate so much that I could actually feel my stomach distending.  That's a good thing, right?  Well not if you're already at the last belt hole anyways...  

The food was good, I especially liked the shrimp tempura.  I haven't had Japanese in a while, but this definitely did the trick.  We also ordered a couple plates of rolls, Q-rolls were one, but I forget the other...  They were also very good.  I especially enjoyed the part where I flung a roll across the table when my chopsticks got twisted.  (Note to self: practice at home first!)  

The atmosphere and the service were great.  Since we had a larger group we had to wait for a bit, but it was not at all unreasonable.  We quickly found parking on the street, but I could imagine that might prove difficult some days.  I did notice on a trip to the boys room a note taped to the can that said:  "Please do not flush toilet paper into the toilet."  That left me with more questions than answers!  Thankfully I only had to go number one...  I'm like Shitbreak from American Pie anyways.  

Overall, a good experience!  I may go back someday!
author: Sean O.

description:
This place use to be good in their original tiny location on the other corner up a few streets.  Once they expanded, the quality of the food went down.

The sauce on the sushi rolls is terrible.  I also didn't like the giant salmon eggs that remind me of bait I used to use for fishing.  :-(
author: Animal K.

description:
I don't get why this place is still around.  It's not as though there is a shortage of Japanese restaurants in The City.

I had gone a few times because friends have wanted to go because it's in the neighborhood and we're too lazy to look for parking elsewhere.  I've sampled several of their dishes and was never really impressed.

Things turned sour one night when I ordered the Chicken Karaage.  There were just six of us, the food was extremely slow to arrive.  (30+ minutes) Eventually everyone got their orders but me;  some time passes and I inquire about it's whereabouts.  A few minutes later, they bring out Chicken Katsu, not what I ordered but I tell them that it's fine and I'll take it anyway.  The waiter gets upset and snaps back (with lots of attitude) that it's the right order and that I was the one that is mistaken.  Not one to dwell on things, I finish my meal and we get our check.. 

Interestingly, there isn't a chicken katsu on there.  It's printed in plain english, k-a-r-a-a-g-e.  I point this out to our server and he just shrugs and throws the bill back on our table.  

Not knowing what was going on, I paid for the additional cost of the karaage over the katsu and an additional cent for their trouble.

Needless to say, this place has landed on my boycott list.  Mediocre food, I can deal with sometimes, attitude too?  Pass.
author: Justin O.

description:
I'm done going to this place. I ordered the soup and it has no taste.  Forget it, I'm not coming here anymore. No taste as in it tastes like water period; there wasn't even salt inside. 

It tastes just like bottle water, except there are noodles and chicken floating around with no taste and it's hot, terrible. Guess what? I can make this dish my self!!! Ingredients: Bottle water, chicken, fat noodles. And then boil it, waola presto changejo, I got a Japanese dish that I can charge like Noriega Teriyaki House. What the fuck man!?

Also this isn't an authentic Japanese restaurant. Basically this is a Chinese run Japanese restaurant. The whole idea is pretty simple.  The general perception is that Japanese food is expensive so they just opened up a Japanese restaurant and charge people more money for their non authentic dishes. 

It's kind of like you making up French names for your dishes that looks like french dishes and charge people more, because the general perception of French dishes are expensive.

I also gotten sick one time after eating here. I should have reported them to the health department.

I suspect that the employees are trying to ruin the business. Gotta be careful on who you hire since you're paying him money.  The last thing you want them to do is ruin your dam business which is your life and blood and your livelihood.
author: Robin T236532i9 W.

description:
For some reason I didn't try the Teriyaki here. I have been avoiding this place based on the name actually. I wondered if they have anything else. It's like going to a place called the Tuna house and asking for halibut. 

No worries. They have a big menu full of things other than Teriyaki. I had the Chicken Karage. It was ok. Tasted like they just dip chicken in their tempura batter. The miso was just okay too. I still think Tanuki does a better miso and fried chicken. Wife had nabeyaki udon. Had huge chunks of a white fish and salmon as well as loaded with other stuff. Strong flavor with the soup base. Maybe a little too much. 

Service was quick and nice.
author: Bruce B.

description: Vegetarian sushi is such a tricky thing.  I am positive that it is not representative of the rest of the menu.  That being said, on with the review.  The veggie tempura roll and avocado maki were the best things we ordered.  The veggie variety in the tempura was particularly nice.  Tamago and futomaki were only decent but not great.  The rice was ever so slightly mushy in everything.  The seaweed salad was tasty but again, nothing special.  Even though there is absolutely nothing wrong with this restaurant, there are other places in the area I would like to try out before coming back here.
author: Heather L.

description: This is the go to for our kids. They have a great kids menu, and give them a little toy. They definitely cater to families. Its no Ebisu, but you wouldn't be there if that was what you were looking for. Its always packed, which means food is turned over. Definitely, something important for cheap sushi.
author: Gwenn G.

description:
I've definitely had better. But I've also had a lot worse.

This place was pretty middle of the road for me. While I really loved the tea they served (genmaicha! my favorite!) and the sushi was really pretty good, the dinners that my family and I ordered were just so-so. The portions were HUGE (a plus) but they were a bit on the blah side. I had the tonkatsu, which was WAY too salty for me (and anybody who knows me knows that's crazy, i love my salt) 

Our service was prompt and friendly, so I won't deduct any stars for that, but i did hear the table next to us request a fork and then ask for it about 4 more times. The poor guy started eating his salad with his hands! Sad!

For how much food you got though the prices were really good, so all in all I can't complain too much. I would probably just stick to the sushi.
author: Tara O.

description:
Was good, now bad. Not hecka bad. Just a little hecka bad. If you want sushi delivered, it is still better than those guys in the back of the phonebook(but not hecka better). Go somwhere else when dining out.
Prices are allright. I don't know why people complain about that. 3 stars is a little much but I'm in a good mood today.
author: Boxxxman J.

description: I ate here about 5 times for lunch.  I always got the sushi lunch specials.  It always good for the price.  Parking wasn't that great even at lunch time.  Service was average.  Sushi was better than the sevice.  Nothing to write home about.  An ok place to pop in and get a sushi lunch special in Sunset.  I ate at the sushi bar and the back room before.  I prefer the sushi bar.  Run of the mill sushi place.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
I love this place!  The fish is always fresh, and the restaurant is clearly family owned and run.  Not the place for a "trendy" sushi experience, but a great place for lunch or dinner.

Have been coming here for years, as have many others in the neighborhood.  We love the gyoza--very light for an item from the fryer.

Give it a try.

P.S.  some other review of NTH seem especially harsh.  Maybe a competitor is messing with their yelp reviews?  Decide for yourself.
author: Rusty M.

description: One perk of finding eateries in the Sunset, is that parking isn't as much of a pain as it is anywhere else. One of my friends took me here since it was close to sfsu, where i reside, and I was impressed with the huge portions for their lunches and dinners. PROS: I've never really had to wait long for a table, and the tea is one of my favorites. The service is usually very efficient, and the servers are pretty friendly. My favorite sushi is one of their special rolls, the Q roll, with the baked salmon. YUM!
author: kim p.

description: Been going here for years! I love this place! Food is delicious and amazing and inexpensive. Favorite Japanese restaurant of all time. Highly recommend it
author: Michelle C.

description:
I give 0 stars for a review of my meal this evening. Possible that the place could get more stars, but I will not be returning to try anything else on the menu.
Sushi is not up to the standard I am used to and I could not eat most of what I ordered. Spicy tuna roll tempura style was so bad. the nori is not roasted and was very soggy, the rice was too wet and the fish was questionable in each roll we ordered. While we were seated at the sushi bar, there were a few overcooked pieces of unagi that I hoped would not get served, but they did get added to a roll and sent out to a table.
Overall I did not trust the quality of the food at all.
author: Gigi F.

description:
So my bf and I were trying to go to the Hawaiian bbq place on Noriega and 21st but it was closed. So we decided to try this place. Thank goodness the Hawaiian place was closed! 

Their rolls were so good! The different combinations were  unique and sooo yummy. 
The prices were great! 
They even brought us complimentary desserts! 1 super yummy huge chocolate dipped strawberry, and a small bowl of custard topped with bits of mango, slices of strawberry and kiwi!!

We absolutely stuffed our selves! We ordered 4 rolls and a bottle of sake and it was under $40! 

The only not so great part was the sauce on the complimentary cucumber appetizer thingy. The sauce had no flavor and had the consistency and look of snot!
author: Esther Y.

description: I really like the service here, and the menu is in color! I love the variety of sushi they have here, and it makes me feel a lot better that they give you a good amount of pieces - not like other restaurants that give you only 4. I love it!
author: Cindy S.

description: DO NOT come to this place if you have a baby! We went to this place for a family dinner and we had 2 toddlers with us. As always, we brought our own homemade food for them. As we were waiting for our food, my cousin started feeding her baby. The waiter came over and told her that there was no outside food allowed, when he could clearly see the food was only for the baby! Then they insisted that it's their policy and that we should not be feeding the baby our own food. Did they expect us to not feed our baby and let them starve??? what if my baby has food allergy?? And they should have told us such policy before they seated us since we had the food containers on our hands, or at least say something before we ordered our food, then we would have a choice to go somewhere else that's more understandable and accommodating. We will never go eat there again!!
author: Mandy L.

description: This place provides decent sushi.  The best thing about this place is that they deliver. When I am too tired to cook, I just order sushi from here and have a good meal. Their fish is really fresh and decent. I am so sad that I moved away from SF. There is no place which delivers in Alameda. Sushi delivery is a common thing in Japan, and I don't understand Americans don't adopt that practice.
author: M N.

description: better than a lot but not in the top tier of sushi and tempura spots in SF. chicken karaage (fried chicken) is heavy of batter and a bit dry but still tasty. it's not the traditional karaage which is considered a snack food in Japan. the karaage here is more like crunchy fried chicken fillets. they even put it in a salad here! kinda like a AZN version of Houston's Fried Chicken Salad.  portions are generous. the best values are the party trays - everything from sushi to tempura starting at $25. another winner is the Combination Lunch which includes Tempura, Beef teriyaki, and chicken karaage. this is served with cucumber salad, miso soup, and rice. only caveat is minimum order is for two. but for only $8.95 per person, you should come with someone seriously hungry to order this.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Mmm, I've had better Japanese food. I had the chicken katsu dinner, which came with soup, salad, and dessert. The katsu was somewhat dry and lacked flavor. I tried dipping it into the katsu sauce to make it taste better, but that didn't really work. The salad was okay, but I've had better (at Sushi House in Alameda!)...and the miso soup was okay too.  I had some of my friend's baked mussels(?), which were pretty good too! The rainbow sorbet, which was HELLA good, very cool and refreshing and perfect for such a warm evening. The bill was not too damaging, and not too pricey since we ordered a lot. 

-1 star for the fly in my friend's glass of water (but the waiter was really nice and apologized)
-1 star for the hair that was in the wasabi
author: Audrey T.

description:
I actually think I thought that this place was alright.

But I've been traveling a lot, meaning not a lot of time to yelp. So this is coming a bit late.

But why is it only getting two stars if i think I may have liked this place? First, it didn't stand out enough in the month that I went that I would remember much about this place when my credit card bill came. More importantly, the OVERCHARGED MY CREDIT CARD. 

Fortunately, I keep my receipts and have a method for making sure restaurants don't overcharge. When calculating tip, round it so that the two numbers before the decimal point is a mirror image of the two numbers after the decimal point. (ie. $39.93). So it's easy to spot an overcharge by a restaurant.

That's how I spotted theirs. My credit card gave me back my $3.00. Not interested in a restaurant that will try to cheat customers out of money.
author: Robert L.

description:
I've been here a couple of times, and the service has been excellent all those times.  The food is not extremely good, but it's still good.  The entrees are big enough to leave you satisfied.  As for price, it's a bit expensive, but not a wallet killer.

I recommend the chicken katsu.  They give you a plateful of white meat chicken.
author: Kev H.

description:
I'm a little bit bias because I know the owners of this find restaurant. 10+ STARS! Really though, this place is good, I love their salads, I always get an extra helping with extra dressing. Free of course. A few times when I am stuck at work by-myself, I order from them and they are always quick and friendly.

This one time with my family, my brother used one hand and dropped some hot soup. That was one of the funniest moment I had eating there. The owner, who knew who I was just looked at him and laughed inside, because I was cracking up. She gave him another one.

Go check it out if you want some good food and a nice family owned style business.
author: David L.

description:
We just had a birthday celebration here.  Great food and the sushi was excellent.  They have some creative variations of sushi.  What impressed the most was the service we received for such a large group.  We had twenty people and our waitress good all the order right.

They gave us a private room in the back so we were able to all sit together.  The prices are reasonable and a great value.
author: William Y.

description: Against my own self-interest, I'm being honest.  If you have kids, love Japanese food, this is the place.  Best Yosenabe anywhere and Wonton soup (yes, nonsequitur, but it's so good!).  Wait staff is kind and attentive.  Decor is tacky, but I couldn't care less, my kids love it.  Just don't go when I go.
author: Ike K.

description:
This is my usual Default Japanese Restaurant. 

#1 Thing to eat: Chicken Karage.. mmm.
Good Portions at a good price.

Sushi will do. Favorites: Dancing Lion

The ladies there are great.

Water is too Lemony so stick to the green tea.
author: Alyson C.

description:
I don't know if many of the reviewers for this restaurant has ever eaten real Japanese food. This Japanese restaurant is Chinese owned, thus the food taste like Chinese-style J-food. They serve the typical teriyaki beef/chicken and California rolls (*yawn*). Nothing really special. The sushi ain't all that, and the food isn't worth the prices on the menu.

I'd recommend going to a real Japanese restaurant operated by Japanese chefs, or even Korean operated Japanese restaurants. At least the Korean owners know how to make decent Japanese food.
author: Joseph N.

description:
I used to come here all the time when since its across the street. It used to be great. Over time though the quality kept slipping. There was a trend that went like this, if they brought in a new menu, food quality went down and prices went up. I think its been a million menus later, so yea, i wouldn't recommend it.

Ignoring the dis proportionality of cost vs quality of food, another thing that will make you not eat here is that you cannot find parking for the life of you. Sunset is usually pretty clear on parking, but its like trying to park on Geary over here.
author: Ray H.

description:
This place is okay for cooked Japanese food, I usually order the Chicken Karage here or the Katsu..but for Sashimi I've had better.  

The portions are pretty good for the price and it gets pretty crowded here sometimes.

Overall I would say its all right if I want some quick cooked Japanese food.
author: Tony C.

description: I ate here for the first time last night.  It was good but not amazing.  We ordered one roll, 2 miso soups, wakame salad, 2 orders of nigiri, and the vegetable tempura.  The pickled cucumbers that everyone raves about were weird.  We also had the baked mussels.  They were a bit too cheesy but not terrible.  For what it was, it was too expensive.  $77 dollars for two people is a bit pricey.  I'm down to pay that much for something delicious, but it was pretty average.  We did have a large beer and 2 small bottles of sake.  I'm still hungover and it's almost 1:30pm.  I will probably go back and try another roll.  It seems like everyone else eating there really enjoyed everything (I heard a twelve year old say that his food was "exquisite" 8 times).  Maybe I just ordered the wrong thing.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
I've been eating here since this place opened on Irving and 25th Avenue, mostly because my friends work there, but the food keeps me coming back. This place has gone through a ton of changes, something is a bit different every other time I come back.

I'd have to agree that this is the typical Japanese restaurant in San Francisco, not much flair, not too many native Japanese speaking staff (if any), and the typical menu. However, the value is unbeatable. It seems as if portions get bigger and bigger yet prices remain very reasonable ($8.95 for entree, salad, soup, and ice cream). 

I always bring my friends there if they're hungry and broke. Specialty sushi rolls there are also quite good although the sashimi is pretty standard.

Service is a mixed bag, sometimes they're quite attentive and sometimes you don't get service for quite a while. It really depends on how busy they are and who's on staff; and I've seen many come and go.

All in all this is a great place to go for all occasions, as long as you're not looking for a place with classy decor, small portions, and exorbitant prices.
author: Felix T.

description:
I think I came here about four or five times now and although it's not as good as Kufuya, it's still pretty decent.  The bf and I both got the lucky cat when we were here earlier in the year.  The sushi could be better but I'm kind of bias since I've been eating so much of it.  Overall, they have pretty cool specialty rolls and when we did come here, they had TAKOYAKI!!! (i crave takoyaki.) but they didn't have it anymore in subsequent visits.

If you have big orders, they do take a while to bring it too you, but they put ALLLLLL your orders on one giant square plate.
author: Natalie G.

description:
When I first ate at Noriega Teriyaki House, it was better than just OK.  The price was decent and so did the food.  My friends told me that its signature item is teriyaki.  Since its name is Teriyaki, I tried its different kinds of teriyaki sets in different visits, chicken, salmon, beef...  

I liked the teriyaki salmon which is cooked salmon wrapped by seaweed, crunchy at the outside and tender at the inside.  Chicken teriyaki was okay and big in portion.  Beef teriyaki was a bit too sweet but still good.  All sets came with miso soup, veggie salad, steamed rice and fruit (usually a few pieces of orange.  BUT, ALL THESE WERE HISTORY....

I cannot remember when it started...all the food items, either cold or hot, were placed in one single plate (of course, not the miso soup).  In the past, they were placed in a box with separated sections.  So, each item was "on its own".  Now, they are all in one plate - the salad dressing and the teriyaki sauce mix - yuck; the orange on top of the teriyaki meat - yuck!  Maybe I'm picky but I believe that presentation is one of the important elements of good Japanese food.  And, indeed, the food do not taste that good now.

I remember that I needed to wait in line for table if I went there on a Friday or Saturday night after 7pm.  Now, I don't see that line and there must be some reasons for that.  With the prices that they change, I would rather to eat something else, not teriyaki there.
author: Roserrele W.

description:
this place is GREAT. their selection is real good and their rolls are GOOD period. my friend and i shared two rolls and i had a chicken salad. the chicken was fried but wasn't dry and it was REALLY good, hence the REALLY. I had the fried california roll and it had a little too much mayo but it was still good. the other roll, dont remember what it was, but it was still good too. 

the last time i came here with my girlfriend, i had the udon here and it was a decent udon, but now i know that they're good for their rolls. 

as for the prices, they're not expensive nor cheap, just right. so if you're wanting some good sushi, i'd go here.
author: Kenny L.

description: Been here a couple times. Sashimi is pretty fresh. Portions are decent. Price is good. However a couple of the rolls I have had seemed like they added MSG to them because I am sometimes allergic to it... I can't say about the cooked foods because I have nly ordered either Sashimi or Sushi from them before.
author: JET T.

description: I've had better. I feel Noriega Teriyaki House is a bit on the expensive side, but for meh quality of food.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Its nothing spectacular but its a good place for sushi.  their dishes are good and the fish is pretty fresh.  Their food is decent priced and allows me to willingly try other items on there and not just stick to one thing.  The fried tofu on the appetizer is alright, not much flavor.  

Tuna Tartar - very good, depending if they fry the shrimp chip good
Sushi Special rolls - very good as well
Tempura - good
Sashimi - pretty fresh, good
author: Vincent K.

description:
I like the the designs at this place, its more Japanesy compared to some other restaurants. My first experience here was better than my second, but that's probably because we only ordered the specialty rolls that time. I really like the one with the scallops on it. Service - soso.

edit for visit 5/23/08- (4 star to 3 star) the four of us came here for dinner last night at around 8 on a Friday (with the place being somewhat busy). I notice that now they have a lot of younger girls working here (highschool/college), which is nice.. but the customer service lacked. One of the girls just kept chatting with a friend or co-worker and took forever to come over (and that was only after her friend told her that we were waiting). So although a couple of them may be cute, they need to practice on their servicing skills. None of the rolls or appetizers were all that great. We had the baked mussels, something tuna, and 3 other rolls. I couldn't find the scallop roll that I once praised. The pricing isn't bad though. And I do like the complimentary pickled cucumbers they offer before your meal, but maybe cut back on the yellow sauce.
author: Elaine H.

description: I dont like this place, i found a hair( not from head) in the sushi, their sushi is tasteless, and udon doesn't look like udon... = ( sorry  will never go back again
author: elly l.

description: i order chicken donburi and raw oysters for delivery. wont do the raw oysters again and the donburi was ok.
author: Linda A.

description:
Noriega Teriyaki is good for a neighborhood place to drop into, but  I wouldn't go out of my way for it.

I agree the chicken katsu is a good choice for dinner.  Enough to share or take home the leftovers.  Not exactly health food, but it's good.

The side of sliced cucumbers is served topped with raw egg yolk, which I always ask them to leave off.
author: Elyn S.

description:
We came here at around noon on a Sunday and I was pleasantly surprised.  They were not busy so the service was good.  I felt the food was good.  I had some salmon sashimi, california rolls, and I also tried the ramen.  My bf had the Sashimi Combo Deluxe that consists of 3 Hamachi, 3 Oysters on Half Shell, 3 Maguro, 3 Sake and he liked only the Oysters and Sake (salmon).  He said the Hamachi and Maguro was mushy.  

I was impressed with the cleanliness of the restaurant as well, especially the restrooms.  I am a bit of a restroom freak and the difference between a clean and not so clean restroom could easily be the deciding factor of whether I will be back to a restaurant or not.  

So, for sure, I will back and hopefully this time around, the sashimi will make a better impression on us.
author: Stella C.

description:
there are a few things i like here. one is the chicken kara-age salad. good deal. they give you a lot. the second is the huge combo platter special which is a good deal if youre ordering it for one person and sharing it with 4 or 5 others. other than that though, i would say for the price, the amount of food is good and the quality is pretty good. the sushi tends to have a little too much mayo, but it's better than a lot of other places that have gross rice. 

one thing they utterly fail in though. they added an option to substitute the normal japanese white rice in sushi to BROWN rice. FAIL.

if youre in the neighborhood for good sushi, i would recommend yumyum fish. its a hole in the wall on irving that has really good sushi. but for main dishes, this is a good place to go that gives more food and isnt as expensive as fujiyamaya up the block.
author: Brian T.

description:
I've been here twice. The first time the sushi was ok for the price. It was reasonably fresh, the fish was cut ok, and the portions were normal.

I went back again 2 weeks later, slightly before the dinner rush and I found the food to be abysmal. The sushi combo was obviously pre-cut getting ready for the rush, or was not that fresh. For example, the red tuna had "extra" red around the edges, ala Freezer burn style.

The slicing was not done well, every piece had connective tissue running lengthwise through it, meaning that you can not take a bite of half a piece of nigiri sushi because your can't cleanly cut through it.

At the end of the day sushi at it's most basic is just raw fish on rice. If I'm going to pay for sushi, I expect that the person making it has had at least some basic training, or hands on experience in how to slice the fish. Just pick fresh fish, and slice the right parts at the right angles! Otherwise I might as well buy a hunk of fish and start going at it like a sandwich!

If you are looking for lower price point sushi that isn't so hit and miss, try Kiki at 9th and Irving. It's even cheaper and arguably better fish.
author: Vic H.

description: Yum-Yum Yummy!! If you love Sushi, then you must come and try Noriega Teriyaki House. My co-worker told me about this place a couple of yrs ago. I love sushi so I brought my fiance in one day. All I have to say is it's one of our favorite places to go when we are in the sushi mood. For me that can be every day. The service is great, all the ppl there are very nice and friendly. It's always packed and parking isn't the best. All in all it's well worth it for some good sushi :)
author: Alma S V.

description:
Had the eel bowl here and the waiter was very attentive and nice.

Update:

Just went back Sat night to celebrate my friend's bday. We went there b/c it was just two blocks from my friends' house and not having to find a parking in SF is heavenly! Definitely saved us time for after hour party! The sushi is OK. Not too many choices.
author: Joe C.

description:
Its almost as if little midgets prepared my pieces of sushi. The pieces were really tiny, especially the baby shrimp.  They really don't give that much rice underneath the teeny pieces of sushi. The sushi was OK and I had to chew through the salmon which wasn't cool to me. I expect sushi to melt like butta in my mouth.They all tasted fine and fresh but just not all that memorable.   The crunchy roll was good, but again, just good... nothing to write home to mom about.

I can get  a better deal for the amount of food at my regular sushi place, even though they don't deliver, I think its worth the drive.
author: Lisa J.

description:
Not my favorite Japanese restaurant. But I'll go if dinner's planned there. The teriyaki chicken is pretty decent, consistently a few good pieces and a few really shitty fatty pieces that you don't want to waste your time eating. Their rolls...I only really get the spicy ones and those work out for me. The ramen broth just tastes salty, not the flavorful salty of shoyu or miso and good ramen places, just salty. I don't recommend it.

It seems to be a sunset hotspot, usually crowded around dinner time. Their customer service is average, one of the waitresses bugs me because she always seems like you're bothering her when she's taking your order. She coughs and doesn't cover her mouth, even aiming it towards you sometimes. I'd rather go to Fujiyama-ya a few blocks up.
author: Tiff L.

description: some years ago, before Kiki, Genki etc, I used to go there a lot. This is the first time for me since they remodeled. Yea, the looks are good, but not their food. I'm very disappointed. I guess I shouldn't order ramen or udon, it was horrible. I've never tasted so bad. I don't mind to pay a little more, but not for something like that. Wish we had dinner at McDonalds instead. What a waste of time and money! Ruined our day! :(
author: The Black Cat C.

description:
Pretty hopping for a Friday night at 9:00pm.  

Can't believe I've lived in the hood for as long as I have and not tried this place.  

Good neighborhood restaurant, tasty, fresh food for pretty reasonable prices. Beforehand, I thought it was a bit pricy for the Sunset, but once I tried the food it made sense.  Only complaint was my Ramen, which was on the Chef's list, came out way after our other food.
author: Rita W.

description:
I have eaten at this restaurant at least once every week for the last couple of years. The sushi isn't the best I've ever had but it's not terrible either. I usually order the Salmon Teriyaki dinner. The portion is pretty generous and I love the green salad that comes with it, the dressing is the best.

The service is always fast and courteous, maybe because I usually pick up my food to go.
author: Pearl R.

description: came here yesterday for dinner with a friend and 2 kids. place was a bit dirty. service: ehh, they forgot the most common thing in a jap restuarant- plates for mixing your soy sauce and wasabi. we did order the 43 piece sashimi & sushi combo, soooo.....?  when they brough over the hamachi kama, they did not bring us any apetizer plates. my daughter ordered the kids combo: wonton udon & chicken katsu. udon was nasty! the packaged udon taste even better than this crap. i would not come here again.
author: Alyce l.

description: no star if there's an option! This place is totally not Baby friendly~If you have a child, do not go there!! THEY DO NOT ALLOW HOMEMADE FOOD FOR YOUR CHILD!!!  The waiter said you have to order kids menu for your kid~ridiculous policy.....understandable if bringing other food from other restaurant.  No matter how good the food tasted, will not go back there again!
author: Chu Y.

description:
Living exceedingly close to Noriega Teriyaki House, I must confess that I eat take-out from here probably two nights a week on average.

Affordable, run-of-the-mill sushi with quick and polite service. The house specialty rolls are disproportionately expensive, but a twelve-piece sashimi plate with soup and rice for under $15 makes up for it.

I'm sure I'll move out of the Sunset one of these days, and when I do, I'll probably never trek out to Noriega Teriyaki House again, but there'll always be a little place in my heart for it.
author: Ash A.

description:
Tried this place way back when it first opened. Tried it again for dinner recently cause my brother was hungover from late night drinking.

Food was not so good. Chicken teriyaki= yuck! California rolls= yuck!

How can you go wrong with the basics? Only good thing was the fast service.
author: Alice T.

description:
This place might not be the most authentic sushi house, but it definitely has a homie neighborhood feel. On most nights, you'll find the place packed, and if you live around the area, you'll probably see many familiar faces. 

The waiters and waitresses are very chill and friendly. Do expect to get your food in a timely manner because the servers are extremely attentive, a big plus.

The portion is good and the raw fish, fresh. And if you're in the mood for some sake bombs, this might be the place because the crowd is livelier than most.
author: b. w.

description:
what do you mean you ran out of ume-shiso?!  okay, so i sat by the sushi bar and tried to order a ume-shiso roll.  one of the sushi chefs didnt even know what it was! what the hell?! its on the frickin menu, you should know what it is!! so  the other sushi guy told him to tell me they "ran out of it."  bull shit.

service here was horrible. most of  the waitress' must have been in their early 20's or younger.   cause they kept talking among themselves instead of helping the customers. helloOo...i need my frickin check please.

i ordered the chicken terriyaki and grilled sea bass combo. i was expecting some bomb ass terriyaki (hence the restaurant name) but it was just ordinary. but the sea bass was pretty good. the meal also came with sunomono (wtf was that orange sauce on top? a mango puree? no thanks), ice cream (omg, there were ice crystals on it! and it was hella frozen!), and miso soup (no complaints here).

bleh...i didnt really like this place. i gave them an extra star just because i liked the sea bass. i would NOT come here for sushi.
author: B B.

description:
Lola's 88th bday. I could only dream to live that long. I love this woman with my whole heart and I know she does not have many natal days left. so I wanna take her someplace special. someplace nice. House of Prime Rib. too much meat. Scoma's. too far from 94122. A. Sabella. what in the hell is that, she says. so I ask, what would you like. she says in her cute little Filipino ahk-sent "Noriega Teriyaki." this place is frickin a mile and a half from her house but whatev, it's what Lola wants. so we reserve lunch, party of 7. dinner would be too damn late, she might miss the almighty Giants game. we order sushi, more sushi, sashimi for the more daring in our sheltered family, various teriyaki dishes, various katsu dishes, and still more sushi. Lola is having a fine time, nibbling at this and pecking at that, swearing she doesn't eat much lately (said the fattest cow in the barn). I am very happy that she is happy. she has loved this establishment for years, since the early 90's when they were located on 22nd Ave. the meal was plentiful and delicious as always. and the service was as accommodating as it's ever been (cheers !). they made my old Lola happy and that's what counts.

-1 star for the sloppy restroom which Lola never used anyway. so why should I bitch
author: Prima D.

description: I always look forward to an order of veggie soba that comes in a iron bowl that keeps the soup piping hot for a long time. It includes a generous serving of about 8 types of vegetable, all under $8. I love their deep fried California roll--9 pieces for $7. Outstanding services today even though they were filled w/ patrons (despite the economic slow down, if I may add).
author: Kim T.

description: I'm addicted to this place.  If you want something not too pricey, Noriega Teriyaki is the place to go.  The caterpillar roll, though not particularly adventurous, is basically the best thing in the history of the world forever.  Also rad is the salmon isobe age, which is some sort of fried salmon stuff drowning in sauce - i don't know what kind of sauce, but it's got vegetables in it, so that's good, i suppose.  well, it tastes good.  AND you get ice cream afterwards, it's like a gift for eating food.  which rules.  anyway, it's really really good, I go probably once a week.
author: Nic M.

description: Not flashy, but not bad. Good if you're in the neighborhood, prices are higher than other Japanese restaurants but the portions are HUGE, the dinner meals are worth two meals easy, three if you don't eat a lot in one sitting. The sushi isn't spectacular but it all tastes good, if similar. Hosts and serving staff are friendly, gets a little slow if the place gets busy.
author: Christopher V.

description: Food is average. Sushi below average. Meats usually overcooked. Portions good and seating fairly comfortable, but wouldn't come here myself.... only come when tagging along with another large party....
author: D T.

description:
Me: single mom, looong day at work, kindergartener in hand by 6 pm. Dinner? I figured we were overdue for a treat, and decided to splurge on delivery. 

Horrible experience. I can't say anything about the food, because I never even got that far. At 6:30 I ordered 3 items for delivery, and told the lady who took my order that I would be paying with a credit card She said "Okay" and hung up the phone. 

So now it's 7:30, and my 5-year old and I are ravenous. The delivery guy shows up, and when I show him my card and ask for the slip, he says I need to pay with cash. I don't have cash on me, I explain, and offer to call the restaurant to clarify and have them run my card. The lady taking orders is now telling me that they can't run the card after the fact, and somehow I've got to magically pull some folding money out of thin air to get my dinner. When I again explained that I didn't have that option, she was not inclined in the slightest to help. She was like, your problem, lady. And then she hung up. I called back and got a man this time, and he actually tried to help, but the solution would have resulted in another half hour wait, and with cold food to boot. 

I'm impressed that this place is doing sooooo well that they can not only throw away money on a given night, but that they'd go a step further by ensuring (with cocky, "I can't be asked to give a sh*t" service) that folks won't order from them again. 

Noriega Teriyaki, y'all ain't the only Japanese delivery in the Sunset, not by any stretch of the imagination.  My advice to you is check your staff members who are acting like Dorsia maitre'd wannabes, and train them on how to write down a phone order. 

Take your Japanese comfort food cravings elsewhere, my friends. The food could conceivably be on par with a couple of area restaurants...but with this level of failure from the very beginning, who wants to take a chance?
author: Heather H.

description: Every time I go back to San Francisco I have to come here. And I go back to s.f. a lot now that i moved to San Diego. I always crave food from here. HAMACHIMAKI PLEASE! I don't know why I always have to order something with hamachi with it. lol The people are always great and so very nice and friendly. I miss it so much T_T Someone please invent a machine that can teleport their food to me.
author: Victoria C.

description:
I went there once and only once.  Our table was situated next to a table with a bunch of little kids.  I didn't have a problem with that really.  About 3/5 the way through eating my meal, one of the kids dropped a toy that rolled next to me so I turned around to pick it up and give it back.  That 20 seconds or so was enough for the ninja waitress to come in, snatch my plate of 3/5 consumed chicken katsu and run off with it.

When I saw my plate was gone, I asked my fellow diners what happened to my dinner.  They said the waitress had collected everything because the other people in my group were done.  Who does that?  What kind of waitress collects a plate with food on it without asking?  I think even an waitress on her first day as a waitress wouldn't do that.  It kind of gave me the feeling they were trying to rush us out because we had been there for over 90 minutes which brings me to my next point. 

After we were seated, about 15 minutes goes by until someone even came to ask us about drinks or ordering.  After ordering, the food did not come out for about 45 minutes and there were only four people in our group.  So by the time we received our food, we had been there for about 1 hour.  We actually contemplated leaving because it was taking so long.

When the waitress came back with ice cream, I asked her about my food.  She just shrugged and left the bill on the table.  I grudgingly paid the bill and only the bill, tips are for good service which was non-existent.  

Paying my bill with my credit card was the last straw because when the transactions posted a few days later, my card was charged not once, not twice, but three times for the exact same amount.  I live about 1/2 miles away and I went back there at least 3 times to try to get the situation resolved no to avail.  They either denied wrong doing despite a printout of the posted transactions from my credit card company's website or the manager was not in.  I ended up having to do chargebacks with the credit card company to get it resolved.
author: James Y.

description:
Eek! Methinks not, indeed. The food is pretty darn tooting nasty. Not even the friendly elderly lady can make me give this place another star (she is really close to it  though [SORRY SWEET LADY!].. but I can't lead the people to think this place is "bearable"). I decided to write in the style of "FAIL!" as I believe it best describes the food.

Tuna Roll (Tekka Maki) - $3.95 (unsure?)
RICE FAIL! The rice was sour and did not taste like regular sushi rice. Made it seem like the sushi roll was left out in the sun for 7 days and a cat pissed on it. 
TUNA FAIL! The tuna was smashed up before it was stuffed unlike other Tekka Maki rolls that chop the tuna in nice SOLID pieces; rendering it tasteless--er (assuming the poor quality tuna had any taste to begin with).

Salmon Mayo Imitation Crab Roll
MAYO FAIL! The rolls had excess mayonnaise that made me want to vomit. I was focused on the mayo, but I think the quality of the roll was not any better.

The Fire and Water Roll
HOT SAUCE FAIL! The hot sauce is the "fire" in fire and water roll, but it also made the roll "vomitrocious". Oh yeah, there was also too much mayo. Stop adding mayo to everything!

Grilled Salmon Lunch Box
MICROWAVE FAIL! The miso soup was lukewarm when served.
RICE AVERAGE - Not a win, not a fail. =|
SALMON FAIL! Dry like my pasty white legs.


Everything was not bad though. Let's reward the good times!
WASABI WIN! It masked the taste of everything I ate to delicious wasabi-ness flavor.
HOT TEA WIN! Hot tea, delicious (like every other place).
author: Resa N.

description: Sushi is good in this place. I'm a sucker of good sushi and sashimi. Cherry blossom, caterpillar, fire-n-ice, was just few of my favorite rolls. I will taste em' all before this year end. This is my pledge.
author: Bernard V.

description: I used to like this place. But this last visit was tremendously disappointing. I ordered the White Pearl roll and the fish it was made with, except the surimi (fake crab) was old and tasted metallic and had an ammonia aroma . When I let the waitress know this and asked for chicken teriyaki instead she argued with me about the quality of the fish and said it was totally fine, i.e. I was wrong, she and the sushi chef were right. I have been a sushi aficionado for more than 10 years and I can tell when fish is off. She brought me the chicken teriyaki, but then still charged me the White Pearl price - $2.50 more. I don't really care about the money, but I really care about their attitude. They never apologized, just treated me like a bad customer. Also, their carpets, menus and bathrooms are dirty. The menu had what seemed like caked tempura batter and soy sauce spattered and stuck all over it. I won't be going here again. Too bad it used to be a great place to relax and get yummy grub...no more.
author: Pam R.

description: I've tried to like this place...  Atmosphere-wise, it's one of the cleaner/nicer spots on Noriega Street.  Food-wise, however, I've been disappointed several times.  The service is fair, but the food is consistently mediocre.  Keep your expectations super low if you decide to come here!
author: C C.

description:
I've been going to this restaurant for years even when the restaurant was in it's original location. Typical Japanese restaurant, you know the usual, some Chicken Teriyaki dish, decent selection of rolls, Tempura, Udon etc... but by no means that's a bad thing.

Food: Like I said typical Japanese restaurant. I've had most of their dinners, a lot of them are good, and they come in pretty good portions. Practically all will come with a salad, Miso soup, and ice cream at the end. So far I haven't had a problem with any of their dishes. The restaurant will on occasion have some unique sushi rolls that you won't find anywhere else, and that's always a plus. Appetizer's I usually skip mainly because you already get a soup with your meal.

Environment/Setup: The location around the restaurant is basically in the middle on Sunset, not many other businesses around other than a few other restaurants a few blocks up, and a Walgreen's across the street. The restaurant is setup very simple and clean. First thing you'll notice is the tree in front of you as well as the sushi bar to your right. The main dinning room is setup very simple, tables and chairs along the sides with tables in the middle separated by partions. They have one separate room for parties although I never eaten in that room. Overall very simple.

Service: It's a mixed bag on this one. it's really hit or miss when it comes to service here. There were times where the service was bad. Usually it was because the restaurant was busy. It'd take a lot of effort to flag a waitress to your table. Also there were times where the sushi wouldn't reach our table until after we already received our dishes. Luckily this hasn't happen to me too often which is the reason I only docked off one star. Most times the service has been ok. Waitresses made sure we were ok, Sushi was made well, and I've talked to one-two of the chefs as well, cool people. 

Parking/Price: Parking around this area is actually decent. Very few times I actually HAD to look for parking. Because there's other businesses around there is more parking, BUT after business hours theres not really other notable restaurant open around there so parking is relatively easy and no metered parking. Price for the meals is not bad for what you're getting. For dinner I usually grab one of the standard dinners, like chicken teriyaki or maybe some salmon. Most of the standard dinners around roughly like 9-10 bucks, and with most of the dinners (minus udon) you get some Miso soup, a salad, and ice cream at the end. so overall not bad, and the portions are relatively good sized too, never left hungry. Of course some dishes could use a little bit more work, but for the most part the dinners are good. When it comes to sushi, it really depends. Of course their standard rolls are good, I never had a problem. Of course I mentioned earlier that the restaurant does try new rolls on occasion some can be good but some can be bad as well. So it really depends on how bold you're feeling.

Quick tips:
Try NOT to go there during peak hours, it becomes really difficult to find a table and when you do the service takes a strong drop.
The food overall is good, there's isn't a huge selection of bento dishes though but the rest of the menu is good.
If you don't feel like driving there, the Muni practically has a stop right in front of the restaurant.

Overall I do recommend Noriega Teriyaki, The service can deter people away, but if your smart about when you go, you'll be fine and you won't run into bad service. The prices are reasonable and the portions are generous, at times the service can be good, the sushi is fine, and it's really accessible to practically anyone.
author: Ryan C.

description: I like coming here because they have a lot of tables so there is almost always no waiting! The food is pretty good too i always get tonkatsu and the spider roll (the spider roll is better at sushi zen though). The service is really good and pretty fast too! Parking has always been easy for me too!
author: Heather C.

description:
i went here a couple of times with my ex. ugh. i can't believe i actually like this place now because of the loser. ANYWAY.

this place has really good udon. and i'm picky about my udon, but this place serves some damn good udon. like seriously good. (there are some other places that serve good udon, though! this isn't the only one.) i like their rolls too. especially the...dragon one, i think. i'm not sure of the exact name, but i'm pretty sure it has the word 'dragon' in it. haha. 

service was good. and the tea was reaaalllly good. one reason i love japanese restaurants is because of the good tea.
author: Betty T.

description: This place is rocking.  I love going here with my buddies to grab something quick and good to eat.  The prices are decent, and the service is great.  Would recommend.
author: Anthony L.

description: The food isn't bad but at the same time it didn't make me want to go back there anytime soon.  The rolls are just average, isn't as tasty as I thought it would be.  Granted the service was great, but just didn't do it for me and it was kind of pricey too.  I just think the rolls need more flavor.
author: Peggy C.

description: I think this place  has very mediocre food that you can make probably at home or something.. This place makes their japanese food in a way chinese way. Their noodles suck here the only thing i think worth eating is like their sushis i guess...but there are tons of other places out there that are wayyyy better than this place!
author: Lucy C.

description: This place is awesome.  You have to try the poki tuna!  It's my favorite.  They also have a special sushi menu. You have to try some of those as well.  Service is great and friendly.  The place is accommodating for large families.  If you decide on a rice plate you better be hungry because they give you a large plate with plenty.  We ordered the chicken katsu that came with salad and rice.  Very healthy portions.  Me and the family come to this place whenever we can!
author: Chris S.

description:
My family's go-to spot for sushi given any night. it's close enough to home that we don't have to drive to geary or irving and it's pretty decently priced for the the taste they provide. the servers are really nice and almost always attentive even when it gets busy, usually friday nights. 

i've ordered for delivery on a rainy day with a hankering for dragon, san francisco, and cherry blossom rolls and they got to us in great time!
author: L B.

description: Overrall a good restaurant. Clean, Friendly, Relaxed Atmosphere. Good sized portions. Good Service. The sushi was great. I really enjoyed their Tiger Roll, Dancing Lion Roll & Union Roll. Mmm! Would definietly go again.
author: Judith F.

description:
12/22 I ate here and have to agree with some of the posters. I ordered the Deep Sea roll and thought it was ok. It was something different than what I usually ordered, but there really wasn't any taste or special about it. Prices are average with other places like Sushi House in Alameda. 

I don't know if I would go back, but defiantly had better at other locations.
author: Jen C.

description: This is a pretty decent Japanese restaurant. I ordered the Spicy Albacore Sashimi, and a San Francisco Roll (spicy tuna, salmon wrapped with avocado and eel). I can honestly say I've had better since the San Francisco Roll seemed as if it were a little above Super Market quality, and the sashimi was kinda mushy (although it was pretty tasty). My cousin ordered the Chicken Teriyaki and also said he had better, and my nephew had the Beef/Salmon Teriyaki which he said was pretty good. The prices are pretty good for the amount of food they give you and the service was above average (it also didn't hurt that they had some cuties working there). It's a hit or miss kinda place if you ask me MY HONEST OPINION.
author: Rommel N.
